txt.en: 'Fair are the tresses of the River-woman's daughter...'
'Under Old Man Willow tree, Tom will go a-roaming...'
'Down by the river-bank, near the rushing water...'
'White bread and yellow cream and berries all a-clutter!'
'A homely house is merry old Tom's house!'
'Hey dol merry dol wither are you going? Tramping in the forest lands and through the rivers flowing!'
'Sing away the gnarling root, at dawning or at gloaming.'
'Come now, the table's laid with honeycomb and butter...'
'Laughing all the day I go - Tom's a merry fellow!'
'It's a fine day for leaping on the hilltops or dancing in the garden!'
'Ho! Tom Bombadil likes his daffodillies...'
'Bright yellow all around, smiling willy-nilly.'
'Return to your gloomy homes; do not be a-waking!'
'What a fine night for singing and dancing!'
Tom Bombadil[mn]
'Likes to go stomping 'round in his boots of leather.'
'Come, Light, and dance with me, and the gloom be slaying.'
'Old Tom, merry Tom, with his waving feather...'
'Water from the Withywindle, soon I will be bringing.'
'Shadow, Shadow disappear, Bombadil is saying...'
A bright-eyed, merry-looking fellow. His face is creased into a hundred wrinkles of laughter.
'No time to be standing about!'
'Bright blue my jacket is, and my boots are yellow.'
'Goldberry, golden locks, flowing like the water!'
'Tom found his Goldberry, River-woman's daughter!'
'Ho now, derry-dol, merry-dol, Tom's a-singing...'
'Evening will follow day, and there's a fire in the hearth!'
'Sleep, all you creeping things, noises nightly making...'
